properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts expected today. A cold front is currently moving eastward across the region this morning. Wind gusts after the passage of a cold front will be near 90 km/h through the middle of the day. The wind will gradually diminish this afternoon. Power outages are possible. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T00:59:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-13T13:55:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1378344942.2020
Area: Picton - Sandbanks Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Low visibilities due to blowing snow at times today. The combination of flurries off of Lake Superior and very strong westerly winds are expected to produce areas of blowing snow. Visibilities will likely be poor in some areas at times due to blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T00:51:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-13T08:52:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2776355764.2020
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow developing this morning then changing to rain. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 km/h with gusts to 80 km/h along the coast. Location: Central and eastern New Brunswick. Time span: Today and tonight. Remarks: An intense disturbance will affect all of New Brunswick today. Snow will begin this morning, then change to rain this afternoon or evening. Ice pellets are possible during the changeover to rain. The rain will taper off near midnight. Snowfall warnings are in effect for northern New Brunswick. Rainfall warnings are in effect for southern New Brunswick and the Fundy coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T06:04:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-13T14:05:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1514022137.2020
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, Grand Lake and Queens County, Woodstock and Carleton County, Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Kent County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Kouchibouguac National Park, Miramichi and area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A widespread and hazardous winter storm will affect the western Arctic today and this weekend. Strong westerly winds will produce poor visibility in blowing snow at times over some areas today, tonight and Saturday. Winds will increase further Saturday night and combined with fresh snow are expected to produce widespread blizzard conditions through Sunday. As the system develops, and timing and location of impacts become more clear, this winter storm watch may be upgraded to a blizzard warning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T02:59:35-00:00

Area: Kugluktuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Maximum Les Suetes gusts: 180 km/h. Time span: this evening through early Saturday morning. Remarks: Les Suetes winds are forecast to begin gusting to 130 km/h this evening and to 180 km/h late this evening and overnight. A general wind warning is also in effect for tonight for all of Cape Breton Island for gusts to 90 km/h. Winds will ease upon shifting to southwesterly before dawn Saturday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T06:05:20-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and strong southeasterly winds expected this afternoon and tonight, as well as higher than normal water levels along the Atlantic coastline. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm, with locally higher amounts possible. Locations: Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia. Time span: this afternoon and tonight. Remarks: Rain is forecast to begin this afternoon over southwestern Nova Scotia and spread eastward across the province, accompanied by strong southeasterly winds. The rain will end late overnight tonight as winds diminish somewhat and shift to westerly. In addition, higher than normal water levels and pounding surf are expected along the Atlantic coast near high tide tonight. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T06:06:14-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lasting blizzard conditions are expected to persist into Sunday evening. Strong southerly winds will shift to westerly tonight, with gusts up to 80 km/h continuing through Sunday. At Paulatuk strong southerly wind gusts will continue to increase this morning, with speeds possibly reaching 120 km/h lasting through this evening until the wind direction shifts. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T03:51:16-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm winding down tonight. The heavy snow snow will taper to flurries by early Saturday. Strong gusty winds up to 70 km/h will accompany this storm causing blowing snow and low visibilities. Snowfall amounts could exceed 25 cm in some regions. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter weather conditions will affect much of southern Alberta until Saturday evening. Snowfall, heavy at times, will spread eastwards to the Saskatchewan border this evening. Northeasterly winds will increase through today and cause reduced visibility in blowing snow, lasting through Saturday for some areas. By Saturday evening, total snowfall accumulations may approach 40 cm, especially over regions in southwestern Alberta. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls and blowing snow developing this morning. Westerly snow squalls will develop off Lake Superior this morning. Local snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are possible by Friday evening. Furthermore, very strong wind gusts to 90 km/h will likely generate whiteouts in blowing snow. Travel on Highway 17 between Sault Ste. Marie and Wawa may be nearly impossible at times, especially along exposed portions of the highway. Conditions will improve Friday night. ### Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T02:24:11-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain ending this morning then becoming windy. Rain will end by late morning. Many areas may receive total rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm. In the wake of a sharp cold front currently moving east through the region, west winds gusting up to 80 km/h will develop. Higher wind gusts are likely over Prince Edward County where a wind warning has been issued. The winds will gradually weaken this evening. For information concerning potential spring flooding in your area, please consult your local Conservation Authority or the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T05:20:32-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow will affect southwestern Saskatchewan Friday night into Saturday. Snow will spread into southwestern Saskatchewan overnight and continue on Saturday. This snow will combine with moderate northeasterly winds to produce areas of poor visibility in snow and blowing snow. Conditions will improve on Saturday night as the winds ease and the snow begins to taper off. Storm total snowfall amounts are currently forecast to be in the 10 to 15 cm range, however there remains some uncertainty to those amounts at this time. This watch will be updated later today as this system develops over southern Alberta and more certainty is gained in where the heaviest band of snow will track. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T02:36:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-13T10:37:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3439166034.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Hazardous winter weather conditions will affect far southwestern Saskatchewan Friday night into Saturday. Snowfall, heavy at times, will spread into the Cypress Hills tonight and continue eastwards on Saturday. Northeasterly winds will strengthen today and persist through Saturday. These winds will combine with the falling snow to produce periods of significantly reduced visibility in blowing snow. The snow will taper off on Saturday night with total snowfall accumulations of 20 to 30 cm in the Cypress Hills and 15 to 25 cm through the rest of the warned area. Snow and blowing snow will also develop along the Trans-Canada Highway corridor from the Swift Current area westwards to the Alberta border, but lower snowfall accumulations are currently forecast. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-14T02:30:06-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: generally 15 to 25 cm except up to 35 cm along the Strait. Maximum wind gusts: 90 km/h. Locations: entire Labrador Coast from Nain to L'Anse-au-Clair and inland to Eagle River. Time span: overnight tonight until Sunday afternoon. Remarks: The snowfall rates will be heaviest on Saturday and will combine with gusty easterly winds to cause widespread blowing snow. Snowfall rates are forecast to ease Saturday night; however, the blowing snow is expected to persist throughout the weekend as the winds shift to strong northwesterlies. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE (March 12, 2020 - Smithers) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Burns Lake because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-14T04:16:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-13T12:17:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0598322686.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain expected will end midday. A cold front will move from west to east across the region causing an end to the rain during the late morning period. Many areas may receive total rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm. Along the cold front and through the afternoon westerly winds gusting to 70 kilometres per hour are expected until this evening. For information concerning potential spring flooding in your area, please consult your local Conservation Authority or the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous wind gusts causing widespread damage are expected or occurring. Locations: western Newfoundland. Maximum gusts: 90 to 100 km/h, except locally 140 in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Time span: tonight until Saturday morning. Remarks: Very strong southeasterly winds will develop tonight then diminish Saturday morning as winds shift to southwesterly. Local enhancement in southeasterly flow typically occurs in the vicinities of Cape St. George, Port au Port Bay, the outer Bay of Islands, Trout River Bay, Bonne Bay, Western Brook Pond and St. Pauls Bay. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
